channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indonesians Vote in Presidential Race Seen as Close
item.description: Tens of millions went to the polls on Wednesday to elect Indonesia’s first new president in a decade, choosing between a populist governor and an ex-general.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: NATO Chief Warns of Duplicity by Putin on Ukraine
item.description: Anders Fogh Rasmussen said there was no doubt that Russia was issuing conciliatory statements while smuggling arms and equipment to separatists.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Anders Fogh Rasmussen, who is in his final months as the NATO secretary general, met with President Obama on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Houthi Rebels Seize a Northern City
item.description: Shiite Muslim rebels captured Omran, one of the main cities in northern Yemen, on Tuesday, a local official and residents said, putting them on the outskirts of the capital.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Taliban Strike in Deadly Bombing
item.description: In one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in recent months, 10 Afghan civilians, two Afghan police officers and four Czech soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber riding a bicycle attacked a village north of Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: World Briefing: More Charges to Come Against Libyan Over Benghazi
item.description: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it intended to file additional charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, the man being held in the 2012 attacks that killed the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and three others.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Troops Repel Attack on Presidential Palace
item.description: Somalia’s government said its troops had retaken the presidential palace in the capital, Mogadishu, on Tuesday after Islamic militants forced their way in and exchanged heavy gunfire with troops and guards.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Fires 2 More Ballistic Missiles
item.description: In test-firing two Scud-type missiles, North Korea was flexing its military muscle even as it was reaching out to Japan and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Swiss Banks’ Tradition of Secrecy Clashes With Quests Abroad for Disclosure
item.description: Laws demanding client confidentiality create a bind for those who cooperate with inquiries into tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Niels Ackermann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paradeplatz, the banking area of Zurich, is under scrutiny as the United States looks to collect information on secret accounts.

item.title: Spying Case Left Obama in Dark, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel last Thursday, he did not know that a German intelligence operative had been arrested a day earlier, and had admitted to passing secrets to the C.I.A.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, before a speech to students Tuesday in Beijing.

item.title: Iran Sends 3 Attack Planes to Iraqi Government
item.description: Delivery of the Su-25 aircraft is the latest step Iran has taken to help Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki battle the forces of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Russian Sukhoi Su-25 planes on the tarmac at Al Muthanna military base in Baghdad last week.

item.title: With Talks Uncertain, Ukrainian Rebels Cling to Hope in Strongholds
item.description: In Donetsk, the eastern regional capital, fighters say they expect a final showdown with government troops soon.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A pro-Russian rebel fighter speaking with reporters on Tuesday in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: On Soccer: World Cup 2014: Brazil Left Humiliated by Germany’s Dominance
item.description: Playing without Neymar and Thiago Silva, Brazil collapsed against a rampaging Germany in Tuesday’s World Cup semifinal, sending the entire country into a funk.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: Miroslav Klose scored his 16th World Cup goal, breaking Ronaldo’s record.

item.title: Germany 7, Brazil 1: World Cup 2014: Host Brazil Stunned by Germany in Semifinal
item.description: Few would have envisioned the home team, so close to glory, being so thoroughly overmatched as in the 7-1 semifinal loss to Germany.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Brazil's Fernandinho reacted after Toni Kroos's first goal, and Germany's third.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Trade Attacks as Tension Rises
item.description: Israel carried out extensive air attacks in response to heavy rocket fire and authorized a major call-up of army reserves for an extended campaign against militants in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israel launched an airstrike on Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: 2014 World Cup Semifinals Result Leaves Germany in Awe
item.description: In the pubs and streets of Berlin, fans of the German national team celebrated its 7-1 win over Brazil in scenes that were as surreal as the score.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Umaru Dikko, Ex-Nigerian Official Who Was Almost Kidnapped, Dies
item.description: In 1984, Mr. Dikko was found in a shipping crate at a London airport along with three kidnappers who had planned to ship him back to Lagos to stand trial.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER

item.title: Iraqi Lawmakers to Reconvene in Effort to Form Government
item.description: The Parliament will convene on Sunday to try to put together a government from Iraq’s often hostile factions, two weeks after a similar effort failed.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Open Source: Iranian Reporter Faces 2 Years in Prison and 50 Lashes
item.description: Marzieh Rasouli was taken into custody to begin serving a two-year sentence at Evin Prison in Tehran for her work.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Israel Warns Gaza Targets by Phone and Leaflet
item.description: The policy, Israel says, is aimed at minimizing civilian casualties in airstrikes. Rights groups say it does not absolve Israel from responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Palestinians carry a man, who medics said was wounded in Israeli airstrikes on a house, into a hospital in Khan Younis on Tuesday.

item.title: Author Held in Beijing After a Spate of Detentions
item.description: Murong Xuecun, a frequent critic of the Communist Party, had said he was expecting a visit from the police after several of his friends were detained.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: President Xi Jinping’s Solo Decision-Making Presents Challenges
item.description: American officials head to China for talks, but President Xi Jinping’s decision-making style and vision of Chinese regional supremacy has changed the dynamic.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Afghan Candidate Stops Short of Forming Government
item.description: The presidential candidate asked his supporters for more time to decide the right course of action as Secretary of State John Kerry prepared to travel to Afghanistan in response to the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York
item.media:description: Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah during a gathering in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Paramount’s Push Into China Pays Handsomely
item.description: While “Transformers: Age of Extinction” was all but guaranteed a certain measure of success in China, its record-breaking numbers will most likely be seen as further validation of the studio’s stepped-up outreach to Chinese audiences.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Visitors photograph a model of Bumblebee displayed in front of Qianmen gate in Beijing as part of a promotion for "Transformers: Age of Extinction."

item.title: Recent Tanker Hijackings Add to Problems in the South China Sea
item.description: Investigators want to know if stolen fuel is being sold for profit or is being used to finance political activities, possibly even terrorism.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Defense Rests Case in Oscar Pistorius Murder Trial
item.description: After many delays, the case was adjourned until Aug. 7, when the defense and the prosecution will make their final submissions to the judge.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at the High Court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday.
